head.title: Despite Pain, Cone Gets Game 1 Nod

hedline.hl1: Despite Pain, Cone Gets Game 1 Nod

abstract.p: New York Yankees say pitcher David Cone will start first game of playoff series against Cleveland Indians (M)

block.p: David Cone is not at 100 percent strength, he is not sure whether he will be able to control a wayward fastball and Manager Joe Torre considers him a five-inning pitcher. But the pain in Cone's right shoulder is not totally throttling him, so he will pitch Game 1 of the division playoffs Tuesday against the Cleveland Indians.
''You'll get it officially tomorrow,'' Torre said today. ''He's always wanted to pitch. He could be on his death bed. He feels good. Yesterday was not a mirage.''

David Cone is not at 100 percent strength, he is not sure whether he will be able to control a wayward fastball and Manager Joe Torre considers him a five-inning pitcher. But the pain in Cone's right shoulder is not totally throttling him, so he will pitch Game 1 of the division playoffs Tuesday against the Cleveland Indians.
''You'll get it officially tomorrow,'' Torre said today. ''He's always wanted to pitch. He could be on his death bed. He feels good. Yesterday was not a mirage.''

After testing his arm for seven minutes on Saturday, Cone will lob a ball at a Yankee Stadium workout Monday afternoon and try not to think about the limitations that he must tolerate because of tendinitis.
''I'm worried about doing the best I can with what I have and going as long as I can,'' Cone said. ''I feel like I'm good enough. I think I've made it over the hump.''
The 34-year-old Cone is confident he can pitch twice if the series stretches to five games and he is also looking for a boost from the post-season excitement.
''I'm hoping the extra energy or extra adrenaline you get during a game will help,'' Cone said. ''It's a variable that's tough to quantify. I hope it's going to be there.''

At least Hideki Irabu made it interesting. Irabu made perhaps his most dependable start since a victory in his July 10 major league debut against the Tigers by striking out six and allowing one run and two hits today in a 7-2 victory over Detroit. But the effort was probably too late to earn him the 10th and final spot on the post-season pitching staff ahead of Graeme Lloyd.
''It's something I have no control over,'' Irabu said. ''I'll wait and see.''

Torre avoided questions about Irabu's future, but said: ''He was terrific. He had a good splitter and good velocity on his fastball. This should have a nice effect on him since he had a little bit of a rocky start.''

Was Torre providing Irabu's epitaph for the season? Probably. Torre has said he wants two left-handers in the bullpen, so the final spot is probably a choice between Lloyd and Kenny Rogers. Lloyd, who had a stiff left elbow last week, pitched a scoreless inning in three of the team's last five games to make himself the leading candidate. Rogers, who would become a $20 million cheerleader if he is left off the roster, worked a shutout inning today.

Irabu, who signed a $12.8 million contract after pitching in Japan, finished the season with a 5-4 record and a 7.09 earned run average. But he was 2-0 with a 1.98 e.r.a. and 19 strikeouts in 13 2/3 innings against Detroit.

''It was only half a season, but the Yankees brought me up to the big leagues and there were so many experiences I went through,'' Irabu said. ''It was a learning process, a learning year and I have learned a lot.''
